title: U.S. Shifts Policy, Rejects Most Chinese Maritime Claims in South China Sea
summary: In a direct but largely symbolic challenge to Beijing, Pompeo says China won't be allowed to treat the strategic waters as 'its maritime empire'. HONG KONG-The U.S. declared its formal opposition to a swath of Chinese claims in the South China Sea, in an unusually direct challenge to Beijing's efforts to assert control in the strategic waters.

title: Bridgewater Loses Claims It Brought Against Ex-Employees
summary: Arbitration panel rules against world's largest hedge fund over its claims on former employees' activities. Bridgewater Associates LP lost an arbitration dispute it had brought against two former investment employees who started their own hedge fund, a rare setback for Bridgewater that could hamper its ability to limit former employees' options after they leave the firm.

title: The Case for Reopening Schools
summary: The harm from lost instruction outweighs the Covid-19 risks.. Everything else about the coronavirus has become politicized in America, so why not a return to school as well? That's the depressing state of play as President Trump pushes schools to reopen while Democrats heed teachers unions that demand more federal money and even then may not return. The losers, as ever, would be the children.

title: Your Sunny Fiscal Update
summary: Federal government spending hit a record $5.005 trillion over the last nine months.. It barely gets a headline these days, but we thought readers might like to know that federal spending for the first nine months of fiscal 2020 hit a record $5.005 trillion. Congratulations to everyone, and especially young Americans. You'll be paying for it the rest of your lives.

title: New York & Co. Files for Bankruptcy, Will Close All Stores
summary: RTW Retailwinds, the company behind the women's apparel brand, expects to liquidate its nearly 400 stores while selling its e-commerce business. The parent company of century-old women's apparel brand New York & Co. has filed for bankruptcy protection and plans to liquidate all its stores after being hurt by forced closures and supply-chain issues during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: When Central Banks Go Green
summary: They'd sacrifice their hard-won independence for environmentalism.. Modern central banks jealously guard their independence-unless it comes to the environment. Witness monetary maestros' growing enthusiasm for using central-bank balance sheets to pursue green-policy goals.

title: Rule of Law in the South China Sea
summary: The State Department finally declares Beijing's claims unlawful.. In the last decade China has intensified its efforts to exert military control over the South China Sea, the vital waterway also claimed in part by Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia and others. While the U.S. has sent warships on freedom of navigation exercises, it has remained formally neutral on these maritime disputes.

title: Congress's Inaction May Halt Immigration
summary: Without emergency funding, USCIS will furlough 70% of staff.. America has lately witnessed radical moves in immigration policy. In June the Supreme Court struck down the Trump administration's repeal of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, known as DACA, which protects some illegal immigrants who came to the U.S. as children. Then the president suspended H-1B and other work visas, keeping thousands of foreign workers out. Next, the administration announced a new plan to repeal DACA, and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement halted visas to students whose universities are now meeting online. Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology sued for an injunction.

title: A Way to Curb Chinese Intimidation
summary: Congress kept companies from cooperating with the Arab boycott of Israel. It can follow that model now.. title: 'Butch Cassidy' Review: The Allure of the Celebrity Outlaw
summary: Despite the author's best efforts, Butch Cassidy comes across as scarcely more than a charming desperado. So why the fascination?. Near the midpoint of "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid," director George Roy Hill's 1969 buddy movie starring Paul Newman and Robert Redford, the outlaws barge into the office of a Wyoming sheriff. Anxious to evade the hard-charging posse tracking them after a pair of train robberies, the duo beseeches the lawman-who has a soft spot for the rogues-to intercede on their behalf with the federal government. Butch explains that they would happily serve in the Spanish-American War, adding gamely: "They don't even have to make us officers." But the sheriff demurs, insisting, in one of the film's most quoted passages: "Now you shoulda let yourselves get killed a long time ago, while you had the chance. See, you may be the biggest thing ever hit this area, but you're still two-bit outlaws. . . . Your times is over and you're gonna die bloody! And all you can do is choose where."

summary: The #BoycottGoya radicals lack even the good sense to follow Saul Alinsky's advice.. It's come to this: They want to cancel black beans.

title: Travelport Wants Lenders Blocked From Taking Over Company

summary: I'm high-risk for Covid-19, but I'm obligated to give my Georgetown students the education they pay for.. title: Princeton and Wilson's Good and Bad Deeds
summary: Nothing about the university's action will impede critical discussion about Woodrow Wilson.. Baher Iskander's "Princeton Sets a Bad Example" (op-ed, July 8) resonates loudly with Albanians because just as he attributes his cherished American life to Woodrow Wilson, Albania owes its very existence as a country to our 28th president. In 1912 Albania had declared its independence, after suffering five centuries of Ottoman domination, only a few years before the 1919 Paris Peace Conference. But in the post-World War I vacuum that existed in southern Europe, regional powers circled little Albania like vultures. Greek military units marauded through southern Albania committing horrific acts of ethnic cleansing and genocide, while to the north Serbs were perpetrating other pogroms against Albanians. Situated in a dangerous neighborhood with coveted access to the Adriatic, Albania had few friends and many enemies. The one friend standing between Albania and the vultures was Woodrow Wilson. If not for his intercession at the Paris Peace Conference, Albania wouldn't exist as a country. Today, President Wilson is revered by Albanians and is a key reason why Albania is one of the most pro-American countries in the world. Tirana, Albania's capital, hosts a large statue of Wilson in a public square that bears his name, and I hope that monument to an American statesman will remain in place until long after we're all gone.

title: With Biden Plan, No Growth May Look Good
summary: Even the slower growth rate of the Obama administration will be unachievable if progressives gain influence over Mr. Biden.. Phil Gramm and Mike Solon describe a 2020 binary "Voters' Choice: Growth or Stagnation" (op-ed, July 9), arguing that Biden administration policies designed to please the progressive wing of the Democratic Party will put a brake on future economic growth. But even the slower growth rate of the Obama administration will be unachievable if progressives gain influence over Mr. Biden.

title: Better Cancer Screening Helps Lives and Cost
summary: The benefits in longevity and cost savings could be immense. These will take time but could upend the way clinical medicine is practiced.. Andy Kessler's "Cancer Screening Leaps Forward" (Inside View, July 6) speaks to a very exciting new methodology in the identification of early cancers. While even his current estimate of cost ($1,000) may seem high, imagine if it could replace mammogram screening, spiral CT chest exams for smokers, PSA and biopsies for prostate cancer, colonoscopies every five to 10 years depending on risk category, etc.; there would be massive savings even at $1,000 per yearly test. Add the savings in cancer treatment if you were only needing to treat early versus advanced cancers and the cost effectiveness is clear. There will be bumps along the road, like picking up breast cancers too early to visualize on mammogram or MRI, but this may also lead to treatments that don't involve invasive procedures. Think of using Crispr technology to actually treat mutated genes or other technologies to turn off adverse cellular activity. You may not even need to wait until the primary tumor is large enough to identify. The benefits in longevity and cost savings could be immense. These will take time but could upend the way clinical medicine is practiced.

title: Scott's Police Reform Could Be a Key for GOP
summary: Sen. Tim Scott's personal experience with racism and poverty, along with his eloquence and his seemingly singular ability to bring out the best in President Trump, are tailor made for these tumultuous times.. Regarding your editorial "Blocking Police Reform" (June 24): For years Democrats have been reaping black votes, while sowing very little that actually improves minority lives. The Senate Democrats refusal to even debate police reform is the latest example of the party ignoring the plight of their constituents to score imaginary points in a game no one wins. For voters like me, who didn't support Donald Trump in 2016 but find themselves equally disgusted by current Democratic antics, Sen. Tim Scott's recitation of his and President Trump's accomplishments for the black community is eye opening.

Manchester City's two-year suspension from the Champions League was overturned on Monday in a stunning reversal that will challenge European soccer's future ability to enforce its rules on excessive spending.

title: Attacking the Hong Kong Dollar Makes Little Sense for the U.S.
summary: The Hong Kong dollar's peg to the greenback would be a strange target in retaliation against Beijing, and doesn't seem particularly vulnerable either. As the Chinese government dilutes Hong Kong's autonomy, the city's currency peg is back in the news again. Promises of retaliation against Beijing have prompted discussions over whether Washington might target the Hong Kong dollar's relationship with the greenback.

title: Chinese Data Center Stock Rally Does Not Compute
summary: New infrastructure stimulus plans will provide a real boost, but valuations have gotten stretched and competition will likely intensify. China's push for cloud-computing infrastructure has sent data-center stocks to the stratosphere. That rarefied air will likely prove too thin for some of them.

title: Actress Kelly Preston Dies of Cancer at 57
summary: Preston had a lengthy career on film and television and at times appearing in films with husband John Travolta. LOS ANGELES-Actress Kelly Preston, whose credits included the films "Twins" and "Jerry Maguire," died Sunday, her husband John Travolta said. She was 57.

title: Who's Excited About Tax Day? The Do-It-Yourself Filers
summary: Armed with just a calculator, the brave go mano-a-mano with the IRS's 170-plus forms and instructions. Most Americans are horrified by the idea of doing their own taxes, without help from a professional or computer software. Not Catherine Fray.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Frac-Sand Supplier Hi-Crush Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Hi-Crush is the latest fracking sand supplier to file for bankruptcy amid low crude prices. Hi-Crush Inc., a supplier of sand used in fracking, is the latest company in the oil and gas sector to be pushed into bankruptcy by low crude prices and the disruption from the coronavirus pandemic that has roiled the energy industry.

title: What Does Being an Ally Look Like? Companies Offer Training in Support of Black Colleagues
summary: Most Popular News. Co-workers of a Black employee at PricewaterhouseCoopers assumed their colleague had a time-management problem when he was consistently late visiting a Chicago-area client.

title: Poland's Presidential Election Remains Too Close to Call
summary: Results set stage for likely court showdown between nationalist incumbent Duda and liberal challenger Trzaskowski. WARSAW-A presidential contest in Poland on Sunday was too close to call, clocking a higher voter turnout than any election in the country's modern history, and setting the stage for a likely court showdown between the nationalist incumbent and his liberal challenger.

title: MultiPlan to Go Public in Merger With Churchill Capital Entity
summary: Health-care-services provider's deal with Churchill Capital Corp. III is valued at $11 billion, including debt. MultiPlan Inc. is merging with a special purpose acquisition company in an $11 billion deal that will take the health-care-services provider public.

title: When Co-Workers Test Positive for Covid-19: What You Need to Know
summary: Employers should immediately tell workers who have been exposed to the coronavirus while protecting the privacy of the affected employee. "Somebody at my workplace tested positive for Covid-19. What are my employer's legal obligations? What do they have to disclose to the rest of us employees and in what time frame?"

title: Interns Seek Solutions to Isolation During the Summer of Coronavirus
summary: Halfway through their internships, young workers are sending signals that more communication makes all the alone time more manageable. Katie Garceran was playing a game of virtual Pictionary with other interns in the Washington, D.C.-based Fund for American Studies internship program from her apartment in Boone, N.C. Suddenly the game screen went black for five minutes.
